creator: list@noduck.net
text: I would like to disable this warning.

creator: slive@apache.org
text:
Why?  It's an error, not a warning.  And it is giving important information.

You should be able to use an ErrorDocument 400 directive to set your own error
message.

creator: list@noduck.net
text:
Yes, it is a valid error for the log file. But sometimes I don't want my HTTPS
server to give a HTTP reply. I don't want to customize the message, I would
prefer if there was just no reply.

I would like to see the behavior of Apache-SSL 1.3 (not mod_ssl 1.3).

Simply not replying is not good behavior from a network application.  It makes
debugging very difficult.

Unless you can supply a compelling reason why this should be configurable, I
don't really see the need.
creator: slive@apache.org

text:
The same way you could argue that an FTP server should recognize when you use
HTTP to talk to it. Instead, when you try that, the FTP server will give you a
FTP protocol error (not an HTTP error). I want to have an HTTPS-only server, if
any error is generated, it should be HTTPS.

The reason is simple, so that it is less obvious that there is a web server
there. Yes, this is some kind of security through obscurity. The goal is to
attract less attention from automated scripts.
creator: list@noduck.net

text:
| The same way you could argue that an FTP server should recognize when you use
| HTTP to talk to it.

Not really. That's a different issue. SSL ist not an application level protocol.

| Instead, when you try that, the FTP server will give you a
| FTP protocol error (not an HTTP error). I want to have an HTTPS-only server,
| ifany error is generated, it should be HTTPS.

HTTPS is HTTP over SSL.
Generating a "HTTPS" error message is impossible, since there's no established
SSL connection at this time. So HTTP is the only way the HTTP server can speak.

| The goal is to attract less attention from automated scripts.

You won't have luck with this strategy. Rather the opposite.
